texts.shortText: Forms a clump of club-like fingers each emerging from a narrow base and expanding distally to a blunt, rounded tip. Each main branch gives rise to short lateral branches, each also emerging from a constricted base. Colour greenish to yellowish brown, wrinkled when dry, but smooth and turgid when wet.  Each branch consists of a thin outer ‘skin’ and is filled with a sticky, transparent mucilage.
Total height typically about 10 cm, but can reach 30 cm, with branches about 1 cm in diameter.

Global: Southern Africa, Australia, New Zealand and sub-Antarctic Islands.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.

A common species found attached to exposed rocks in the mid to low intertidal. Stores water in the mucus filling the branches and able to tolerate considerable water-loss when exposed at low tide, becoming flaccid and wrinkled, but regaining water when submerged again at high tide.

Considered a valuable source for the discovery of bioactive compounds of bacterial origin active against human pathogens.
Spores produced by sunken conceptacles about 0.4 mm in diameter that are visible as dark spots on the branches.

Albakosh, MA, Naidoo, RK, Kirby, B & Bauer, R (2016). Identification of epiphytic bacterial communities associated with the brown alga Splachnidium rugosum. Journal of Applied Phycology, 28, 1891–1901.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 390).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 158).
